src:
Els indignats xilens volen canviar la Constitució
La situació d’excepcionalitat ha capgirat el dia a dia de tot el país, sumit en una protesta que no para

02 Nov 2019, 00:04

Desenes de tanques bloquegen l’accés del capdamunt del passeig Bulnes, a tocar de la Moneda. Els estudiants han convocat una acampada i diverses assemblees sota el lema “Si Piñera no se’n va, nosaltres tampoc”, però a l’hora prevista no hi ha ni estudiants ni tendes. Només desenes de policies custodiant l’espai i una fortor de gas pebre que contamina l’ambient de tota la ciutat des de fa dies. “Ens han barrat el pas i ens han amenaçat amb detenir-nos”, denuncia Valentina Miranda, una de les portaveus del col·lectiu.
El calendari ha donat una treva de quatre dies a manifestants, govern i policies. Uns dies festius que serviran per recuperar forces, però que molts han aprofitat per participar en els centenars d’espais de debat que ha obert de forma autoconvocada la ciutadania. Comunitats de veïns, artistes, membres de l’acadèmia, feministes, comunicadors i esportistes es reuneixen aquests dies en assemblees obertes i cabildos arreu del país. Es parla de moment constituent, que podria desembocar en una nova carta magna que substitueixi la Constitució actual, dissenyada i establerta el 1980, sota la dictadura de Pinochet.
A l’Estadi Monumental, recinte del Club Esportiu Colo-Colo, més de 1.000 persones de totes les edats discuteixen sobre les principals demandes del moviment i l’aportació que pot fer el club i el món de l’esport, en general, a la crisi. La comunitat de veïns Blas Cañas, una de les més grans del centre de Santiago, ha posat en marxa una olla comú per alimentar unes 80 persones que participen en els debats i les mobilitzacions. “Avui preparem arròs amb verdures i peix per atendre els que hi participin, perquè volem fer comunitat i ajudar els veïns”, comenta Carola Carmona, una de les cuineres.
Divendres va fer dues setmanes que van començar les protestes més massives des del retorn de la democràcia. Dues setmanes que han canviat la manera com la societat xilena es mira a si mateixa, però a un cost que encara no se sap com serà d’alt.
Escombraries acumulades
El país segueix immers en una situació d’excepcionalitat que ha capgirat el dia a dia de la ciutadania i que ha canviat la imatge de les principals ciutats del país. Santiago està molt lluny de la capital llatinoamericana dinàmica, neta i sempre a ple funcionament que aspira a ser. Està bruta i deixada, plena de pintades a les parets, amb edificis incendiats o ruïnosos i molts bancs i supermercats que no funcionen, saquejats o cremats. Les escombraries s’acumulen als carrers perquè el camió de la brossa fa dies que no passa i molts semàfors estan apagats.
“Som un negoci familiar. Donem suport a les mobilitzacions. Sisplau, no ens saquegeu”, es llegeix a la porta d’una pastisseria tancada del centre de la capital.Eduardo Bravo és el propietari d’una botiga de queviures de barri. Un negoci familiar que pares i fills han protegit fent torns de guàrdia dins l’establiment a les nits. De dia han sigut els principals proveïdors d’aliments de la zona: “Hem hagut de treballar moltes més hores. La mercaderia no ens arribava i l’hem hagut d’anar a buscar directament al polígon alimentari quan s’acabava el toc de queda perquè no teníem el salconduit per circular de matinada -explica-. El preu de la farina s’ha quasi triplicat. Ha sigut un caos. La gent ho ha comprat tot, embogida per l’alarmisme dels mitjans, que han insistit molt en la falta de provisions, i pel toc de queda, que s’ha arribat a allargar fins a 11 hores”, continua.
Tot i que els treballadors intenten recuperar la normalitat i anar a la feina o portar els fills a l’escola, encara hi ha molts problemes de transport que provoquen retards d’una o dues hores.
Les universitats continuen tancades i molts establiments obren només al matí o han reduït l’horari d’atenció al públic. “Normalment tanquem a les 12 de la nit, però aquests dies ho hem fet a cap a les 7 o les 8 del vespre. Ha baixat el nombre de clients perquè obrim menys hores i els que venen no es queden tanta estona”, comenta Alexander Pérez, cambrer d’un bar-restaurant del centre.
Violacions de drets humans
Han passat quasi 30 anys des del final de la dictadura, però per a alguns la crisi ha fet ressorgir els fantasmes del passat més recent de Xile: “Jo tenia 20 anys el 1973, quan va començar la dictadura, i em pensava que mai més tornaria a viure la repressió d’aquells dies, el toc de queda i els militars al carrer. No hauria imaginat mai que els meus nets formarien part d’aquesta situació”, lamenta l’Amanda, que protesta en la cassolada del seu barri.
La Fiscalia investiga la mort de 23 persones durant l’estat d’emergència de la primera setmana i 840 deníncies per violacions de drets humans. Entre aquestes hi ha la presentada per l’estudiant de medicina José Maureira, que, segons l’Institut Nacional de Drets Humans, “va ser despullat i va patir abusos sexuals en un context de tortura”. El jove ho relata: “Els policies em van obligar a cridar la meva identitat sexual mentre em pegaven. M’han amenaçat i han intimidat la meva família i els meus amics. La meva vida ha canviat radicalment els últims dies i he decidit marxar a Espanya per acabar els meus estudis. Xile ja no és un país segur per a mi”. Fa dies que molts altres xilens pensen el mateix.
Madrid acollirà la cimera climàtica
La Convenció Marc sobre el Canvi Climàtic de l’ONU (UNFCCC) va acceptar ahir l’oferta del govern espanyol d’acollir a Madrid la cimera anual d’aquest organisme, la COP25, que s’havia de celebrar a Xile al desembre però que el govern de Sebastián Piñera va haver de suspendre per les protestes massives que continuen omplint els carrers d’aquell país. L’executiu de Pedro Sánchez es va oferir de seguida al xilè per acollir la trobada internacional, que havia de portar més de 25.000 persones al país andí, i ahir l’organisme responsable dins de l’ONU va anunciar formalment que la COP25 se celebrarà a Madrid en les dates previstes, del 2 al 13 de desembre. Xile, de fet, va assumir el compromís d’acollir la COP25 a finals de l’any passat, quan el president brasiler, el negacionista Jair Bolsonaro, es va estrenar en el càrrec decidint rebutjar organitzar la cimera climàtica, que en un primer moment estava prevista al Brasil.
text:
The indignant Chileans want to change the Constitution
The situation of exceptionality has turned the daily life of the whole country, plunged into a protest that does not stop

02 Nov 2019, 00:04

Dozens of tanks block access to the top of the Bulnes promenade, near the Currency. The students have summoned a camp and several assemblies under the slogan "If Piñera does not leave, we do not" either, but at the scheduled time there are no students or stores. Only dozens of police officers guarding space and a gas pepper forter that pollutes the city's environment for days. "They have blocked us and threatened to stop us," denounces Valentina Miranda, one of the spokespersons of the group.
The calendar has given a four-day truce to protesters, government and police officers. On holidays that will be used to recover forces, but many have taken advantage of it to participate in the hundreds of spaces for debate that have opened the citizens' self-conveniences. Communities of neighbors, artists, members of the academy, feminists, communicators and sportsmen meet these days in open assemblies and councils around the country. There is talk of a constituent moment, which could lead to a new machine letter that replaces the current Constitution, designed and established in 1980, under the dictatorship of Pinochet.
At the Monumental Stadium, the Colo-Colo Sports Club, more than 1,000 people of all ages discuss the main demands of the movement and the contribution that can be made by the club and the world of sport, in general, to the crisis The community of neighbors Blas Cañas, one of the largest in the center of Santiago, has set up a common pot to feed about 80 people who participate in debates and demonstrations. "Today we prepare rice with vegetables and fish to attend to those who participate, because we want to make community and help the neighbors," says Carola Carmona, one of the chefs.
Friday two weeks ago the massive protests began since the return of democracy. Two weeks have changed the way in which the Chilean society looks at itself, but at a cost that is still unknown how high it will be.
Garbage accumulated
The country is still immersed in a situation of exceptionality that has turned the daily life of citizens and that has changed the image of the main cities of the country. Santiago is very far from the dynamic Latin American capital, clean and always in full operation that it aspires to be. It is dirty and left, full of painted on the walls, with burning or ruined buildings and many benches and supermarkets that do not work, looted or burned. Garbage accumulates in the streets because the junk truck has not passed many days and many traffic lights are turned off.
"We are a family business. We support mobilizations. Please, do not slaughter us, "he reads at the door of a closed pastry shop in the center of the capital. Edward Bravo is the owner of a grocery store. A family business that you stop and children have protected by keeping your guard room in the establishment at night. By day they have been the main suppliers of food in the area: "We had to work many more hours. The goods did not arrive and we had to go straight to the food polygon when the curfew was over because we did not have the safe to move in the morning, "he explains. The price of flour has almost tripled. It has been a chaos. People have bought everything, crazy about the alarmism of the media, who have insisted a lot on the lack of provisions, and the curfew, which has been extended to 11 hours, "he continues.
Although workers try to regain normality and go to work or take their children to school, there are still many transport problems that cause delays of one or two hours.
The universities are still closed and many establishments open only in the morning or have reduced the hours of attention to the public. "Normally close at 12 in the evening, but these We did it for 7 or 8 at night. The number of customers has dropped because we have less time to open and those who sell do not stay that long, "says Alexander Pérez, a bar-restaurant waiter from the center.
Violations of human rights
Almost 30 years have passed since the end of the dictatorship, but for some the crisis has made the ghosts of the most recent past of Chile resurrect: "I was 20 years old in 1973, when the dictatorship began, and I thought never again The repression of those days, the curfew and the military in the street would once again live. I would never have imagined that my grandchildren would be part of this situation, "Amanda complains, who protests in the cassolade of her neighborhood.
The Prosecutor's Office investigates the death of 23 people during the state of emergency of the first week and 840 denunciations for human rights violations. Among these is the one presented by the medical student José Maureira, who, according to the National Institute of Human Rights, "was stripped and suffered sexual abuse in a context of torture." The young man tells him: "Policemen forced me to call my sexual identity as they stuck. They have threatened and intimidated my family and my friends. My life has changed dramatically in recent days and I have decided to go to Spain to finish my studies. Chile is no longer a safe country for me. " It has been days that many other Chileans think the same.
Madrid will host the climate summit
The UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) yesterday accepted the offer of the Spanish government to host the annual summit of this body, the COP25 in Madrid, which was to be held in Chile in December that the government of Sebastián Piñera had to suspend by the massive protests that continue filling the streets of that country. The executive of Pedro Sánchez immediately offered to Chile to host the international meeting, which had to bring more than 25,000 people to the Andean country, and yesterday the responsible body within the UN formally announced that the COP25 will be held in Madrid on scheduled dates, from 2 to 13 December. Chile, in fact, assumed the commitment to host COP25 at the end of last year, when the Brazilian president, the denialist Jair Bolsonaro, was released in office deciding to refuse to organize the climate summit, which initially It was planned in Brazil.
